comment.author: 74004041@N06
comment._content: Fort Macquarie tram sheds in the background I wonder?.

comment.author: 83309992@N00
comment._content: The 1926 RR in the foreground was owned by William Szarka of Stanmore, Sydney. He owned several theatres such as the Enmore. The car was reg'd 180-944 and the chassis nb was 61SC, coachbuilt by Windovers in the UK.

comment.author: 61766673@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/83309992@N00] André, according to the chassis cards, #61SC was an Allweather body with artillery wheels. This looks like a different car to me......

comment.author: 83309992@N00
comment._content: It was an "all-weather special limousine", and according to Tom Clarke - who is the RR of historians - the roof could be folded "à la Tickford". That's where the "all-weather" comes into the picture ;o)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Mr William Szarka (see note) was the Director of Hoyts by 1932 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/2303360 With his wife in 1935 - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=82140#

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/74004041@N06] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/83309992@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/61766673@N00] Hi all, great discussion and research thank you! In the catalogue record description it says: 'Image depicts a scene in Macquarie Street, Sydney, NSW. Fort Macquarie tramsheds at rear. Four men posed and facing w. to Circular Quay.' Now we know it was William Szarka! Thank you park-ward for the lead and beachcomber for the links. Such specific information is great to be able to put in our database. This event must be linked to the following photographs on board SS SIERRA, which transported the equipment! See this article: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29610527 AND, there's a couple more from the collection from the same event. Hopefully there will be something in the newspapers about who these people actually were.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] That's great - the jigsaw comes together! It must have been an exciting moment - "the first sound picture taken in Australia" as the SIERRA came up the Harbour, presumably docking at Bennelong Point, in front of these people, the welcome party. Some of the passengers arriving on the SIERRA on 8/8/1929 are listed here, but nothing specific about the recording equipment / truck. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16574294

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes, particularly with those aeroplanes zooming by as part of the official welcome. Thanks for that list, I bet some of those people are depicted in these photographs.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 29903115@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/83309992@N00] Is it a Phantom, or a Twenty? I'd say a Twenty?
